dt: {bc}to catch or take in or as if in a trap {bc}{sx|entrap||}

dt.t: these mountains {wi}trap{/wi} rains and fogs generated over the ocean

dt: {bc}to separate out (something, such as water from steam)
{bc}to catch (something, such as a baseball) immediately after a bounce
{bc}to block out (a defensive football player) by means of a trap
{bc}to stop and gain control of (a soccer ball) with a part of the body other than the hands or arms
{bc}to make a defensive trap in basketball

pt: {sc}catch{/sc} {sc}capture{/sc} {sc}trap{/sc} {sc}snare{/sc} {sc}entrap{/sc} {sc}ensnare{/sc} {sc}bag{/sc} mean to come to possess or control by or as if by seizing. {sc}catch{/sc} implies the seizing of something in motion or in flight or in hiding.

pt.t: {it}caught{/it} the dog as it ran by

pt: {sc}capture{/sc} suggests taking by overcoming resistance or difficulty.

{sc}trap{/sc} {sc}snare{/sc} {sc}entrap{/sc} {sc}ensnare{/sc} imply seizing by some device that holds the one caught at the mercy of the captor. {sc}trap{/sc} and {sc}snare{/sc} apply more commonly to physical seizing.

pt.t: {it}entrapped{/it} the witness with a trick question

pt: {sc}bag{/sc} implies shooting down a fleeing or distant prey.

shortdef: to catch or take in or as if in a trap : entrap
to place in a restricted position : confine
to provide or set (a place) with traps

dt: {bc}to adorn with or as if with {a_link|trappings}

et: Middle English {it}trappen{/it}, from {it}trappe{/it} caparison, from Anglo-French {it}trape{/it}, probably from Medieval Latin {it}trapus{/it} cloth, by-form of Late Latin {it}drappus{/it}
shortdef: to adorn with or as if with trappings

dt: {bc}a trap for the unwary or unsuspecting {bc}{sx|pitfall||}
{bc}a concealed explosive device contrived to go off when some harmless-looking object is touched

shortdef: a trap for the unwary or unsuspecting : pitfall
a concealed explosive device contrived to go off when some harmless-looking object is touched
